subject: Added discrete threshold trigger support
commitMessage:
Added discrete threshold trigger support

Implemented discrete threshold logic
Discrete trigger with empty threshold array is handled as 'onChange'
Added unit tests coverage for discrete trigger

Supported scenarios:
-discrete threshold with value and dwell time
-discrete threshold with value, without dwell time
-discrete trigger without threshold ('onChange')

Tests:
-Unit tests passed

Change-Id: Id60a48f4113bd955d97e154888c00d1b6e5490af
Signed-off-by: Szymon Dompke <szymon.dompke@intel.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as f763c9e3bbe0f86a4a41e7bb0dc70bffde0af9b2 by Krzysztof Grobelny

I propose to use short version with indirect case to bool
if(thresholdValue)
Done
you can do like this *thresholdValue
Done

you are comparing double to std::optional<double>, I think it should be 
value == *thresholdValue
Done
std::optional can be compared with T, it return true when equal, false when optional is empty or not equal, but since you checked before if there is value in optional it looks better.
does it make sens to move bool type?
Done
You can add else here, because value won't change between 58 line an 63
Done
It seems that startingValue has the same value as previousValue, am I right? Or I am missing the point. I do not see a point for startingValue variable

Consider following case. We get following readings, all within dwellTime timeframe: 10.0 -> 11.0 -> 13.00 -> 11.0 -> 10.0. The startingValue is set to 10.0, startTimer(...) is called, and previousValue is updated after every new reading. The timer should be cancelled only after we encounter value 10.0 again during dwellTime. We need to store this value for proper comparison.

ex. you have a sensor that only have two values - open and close. User want to know that open state was set for 10 seconds. If state change to close below 10 seconds than it means that you should drop the timer. Am I right?
And this is exactly how this code is supposed to work. Two-value sensor is the only case where startingValue == previousValue.
I can see the point, it is only affecting the "OnChange" option. But the "OnChange" option should not use the timer and DwellTime according to Redfish specification and Telemetry dbus interface
You are right, onChange trigger should not use dwellTime, fixed in latest patchset.
It should not be optional here. You do not check inside the function if optional has a value. Consider to remove TriggeringContext. You need only timestamp and value here.

I think this needs to stay, we need reference to optional triggerringContext, because:
- timestamp and value might be updated in case of 'onChange' discrete trigger
- after calling commit, we need to set it to std::nullopt as this is checked in sensorUpdated (instead of passing 'bool& dwell').

triggerringContext is also given a value before each startTimer() call so I was not checking if it had a value.

I based my opinion on how it is done in numeric threshold. value and timestamp should not change over time after timer started.
ex. there is a sensor that have two readings - open and close, user only wants to commit an action when readings is set to open for 10 seconds and more. If we commit an action with new value - close - it is problematic for user to understand what happened

I agree - this might be problematic. But Currently if we create onChange trigger with 10s dwell time, and following sequence 10, 11, 12, 3000, 3001 (all during dwellTime, and lets assume that previous reading had value 9).
- we can commit 10, which started the timer, but 4 different reading happened after it.
- we can commit 3001 as it was the last update during the dwellTime

which one should be choosen?

Ok, I can see your point. Thanks for explanation. I thought that we should not take in consideration DwellTime when "OnChange" is set for discrete threshold. Ref: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/xyz/openbmc_project/Telemetry/Trigger.interface.yaml#L59
You are right, onChange trigger should not use dwellTime, fixed in latest patchset.
Maybe instead adding postfix put those classes in to namespaces: discrete and numeric. Up to you
Good idea - this will make things more readable
Are you sure that name for Discrete thresholds should be unique?
Yes - it was discussed with Piotr Matuszczak
Can you be more specific? I do not see in Redfish spec that unique name for discrete threshold is required
Up to you if unique name is required
nit: is there a reason for it to be in cpp file?
Done
Because of this we need to delete copy and move constructor, if copied by accident it will be hard to detect errors.
This particular code was removed in latest patchset. (Discrete threshold was split to Discrete and OnChange)
Same situation applies to &dwell, it is only small part of details but to make it work you need to ensure ThresholdDetail is neither copyable nor moveable.

I see, as a solution to prevent any future/possible reallocation consequences, getDetails() will be called from starTimer as well, instead of passing &dwell. I also removed copy and move constructor for discrete trigger, so passing 'this' in lambda should be safer.
nit: triggeringContext->timestamp, triggeringContext->value
This particular code was removed in latest patchset. (Discrete threshold was split to Discrete and OnChange)
return object should not be const, below we return const pointer which is different.
In my opinion it is better to not use static, c++ way of creating functions visible only in current file is to create anonymous namespace
Done
Done
nit: sut = makeThreshold(0ms, 90.0); it just reads better.
Done

This one deserve own name:

INSTANTIATE_TEST_SUITE_P(
    _, NoCommitWhenDeletedBeforeDwellTimeExpires, // for example of course.
    Values(DiscreteParams()
               .DwellTime(200ms)
               .Updates({{0, 1, 80.0, 300ms}})
               .Expected({})));
OnChange with DwellTime cases are removed, so I think it is no longer needeed
empty namespace?
It's annonymus namespace. Works like static function but it is C++ way of doing it.
Ack

Krzysztof Grobelny Mar 30
In my opinion it is better to not use static, c++ way of creating functions visible only in current file is to create anonymous namespace
Why it is double? The timestamp parameter for commit() methods is of type uint64_t
good catch, will fix.
Done
You are already in numeric namespace. I guess that you can remove "::numeric" from this and other lines
Actually, we are in action::numeric namespace, which is different from numeric. This won't compile if I remove it.
Maybe change the order? For example: numeric::action::LogToJournal

For me current hierarchy makes more logical sense, and I would rather not change it.
  - numeric
  - discrete
  - action
    - numeric
    - discrete
      - onChange

::numeric and ::discrete are used for types definitions, while action::numeric, action::discrete, and action::discrete::onChange is used for actions
This also allows to make generic actions, not specialized for trigger type - like action::UpdateReport
It seems irrelevant to whole patch. Can you undo it? Thanks in advance

It is incorrect for clang compiler, and otherwise CI won't build this patch.
The only reason it was compiling before, was that gcc was used, which allowed it.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46114214/lambda-implicit-capture-fails-with-variable-declared-from-structured-binding
Why do you want to use clang? CI uses gcc or I am missing something
Look like CI started using clang.
Ack
It seems that CI is using g++ once again. I removed this 'fix'. It is possibly still not compatible with C+17 standard, but I will create separate path set for this issue.
Is it needed? Why not just return make_shared<>(...);
Done
